wikipedia_page.main: William Sturch (1753?–1838) was an English Unitarian theological writer.

response: Elisabeth Jesser Sturch was born in 1789 in London. Her father, William Sturch, was a wealthy Unitarian ironmonger. In 1821, she married Dr John Reid. Dr Reid had inherited land in Northumbria and on the River Clyde at Glasgow that had become valuable as the port grew in size. His death in July 1822 gave Mrs Reid an independent income, which she used to help various philanthropic causes.
* William Sturch, theological writer, was one of the original congregation.

Reid married Elizabeth Jesser SturchSybil Oldfield, ‘Reid , Elisabeth Jesser (1789–1866)’, rev. Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, May 2011 accessed 30 March 2013 doi:10.1093/ref:odnb/37888 in 1821; she was the daughter of William Sturch. He left his wife an inheritance which she used to found Bedford College.

William Sturch, who had attended one of the services, wrote a tract condemning Kentish's Preterist views, in which he was said to have "overstated" the fulfilment of Christ's prediction of the siege and destruction of Jerusalem, and under-stated the natural evidences of the immortality of man.
